CU python SDK it's just a library that you can use with cubay it's
intended for managing uh array clusters and it uses cubay under the hood so
basically it's producing the VL manifests that are consumed by cubay it abstracts that from you so you
as a user you wouldn't be needing to work with kubernetes as long as that
application that you develop is deployed then you just interact with the application through whichever web interface you want to interact with you

the director design pattern there so the director is just a class that allows you
the highest level of abstraction so this is all the code you need for for example to create a cluster this code is a bit
prescriptive because you can see here that it's saying build small cluster but
that means that you don't have a lot of configur configurability there you're just going to ask it to build a small
cluster it supports four types basic small medium and large large has five workers medium three workers small one
worker basic only a head node and that's it and then after you create the cluster
definition you just create it and you're going to have a cluster up and running now the Builder is a is another class that has
that gives you more control so instead of the director where you're asking uh for a cluster with a T-shirt size with a
builder now you can pass in more parameters and here for example we're passing for the head note the CPU limit
is three we're for the worker groups we're specifying the number of replicas and there's a whole lot more attributes
than this what I'm showing here most of them have default values the ones you choose are the ones you override those
default values and finally on the lowest level you would have the row API and
within that row API you define your cluster definition whichever way you want it gives you like the most
flexibility you can anything you can do with a yaml file you can do with the row API and then it can create your cluster
for you now for those who are familiar with implementing the director pattern and using factories you would know that
